dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so I read this article, right? And it's like, completely flipping everything we thought we knew about weight loss on its head.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I read this article, right? And it's like, completely flipping everything we thought we knew about weight loss on its head.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Uh, what's the big revelation this time? Is it about, like, intermittent fasting or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Uh, what's the big revelation this time? Is it about, like, intermittent fasting or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, no. Actually, it's about... sitting. Get this: the time you spend sitting down might actually *help* you lose weight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, no. Actually, it's about... sitting. Get this: the time you spend sitting down might actually help you lose weight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We believe that the internal body scales give an inaccurately low measure when you sit down. As a result you eat more and gain weight, says Ohlsson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, what?! But everything I've ever heard is like, "standing desks, move more, avoid being sedentary!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what?! But everything I've ever heard is like, standing desks, move more, avoid being sedentary!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? This is from researchers at the University of Gothenburg in Sweden. And they're saying our understanding of internal weight regulation is, quote, "completely backwards."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? This is from researchers at the University of Gothenburg in Sweden. And they're saying our understanding of internal weight regulation is, quote, completely backwards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The quote "completely backwards" does not appear in the provided article. The article does mention the university: "Researchers at Sweden's University of Gothenburg believe they may have discovered the body's second known system for regulating body weight."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the brain thinks standing is bad? How does that even make sense?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the brain thinks standing is bad? How does that even make sense?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently, the brain, uh, somehow believes that standing for long periods is a sign of *weight gain*. And they figured this out with mice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently, the brain, uh, somehow believes that standing for long periods is a sign of weight gain. And they figured this out with mice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The weight of the body is registered in the lower extremities. If the body weight tends to increase, a signal is sent to the brain to decrease food intake and keep the body weight constant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mice? How do you test that on mice? Like, put them on tiny treadmills?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mice? How do you test that on mice? Like, put them on tiny treadmills?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, they did this really peculiar thing. They implanted weights, like little capsules, into the brains of mice. Some had actual weight, about 15% of their body mass, and a control group had empty capsules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, they did this really peculiar thing. They implanted weights, like little capsules, into the brains of mice. Some had actual weight, about fifteen percent of their body mass, and a control group had empty capsules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The study was conducted by implanting weights into the bellies of mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that's wild. So, what happened to the mice with the extra weight in their brains?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that's wild. So, what happened to the mice with the extra weight in their brains?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The ones with the *added* weight, um, actually gained *more* white body fat. It's like their brain was tricked into thinking they were heavier, so their body stored more fat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The ones with the added weight, um, actually gained more white body fat. It's like their brain was tricked into thinking they were heavier, so their body stored more fat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After a few weeks, the two groups had nearly the same weight, with the mice implanted with added weight apparently making up the difference by shedding white body fat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. And what about leptin? I thought that was, like, the big hormone for regulating body fat?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. And what about leptin? I thought that was, like, the big hormone for regulating body fat?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what we *thought*. But this new research suggests leptin's effect is actually, like, pretty negligible compared to this new mechanism they've found.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what we thought. But this new research suggests leptin's effect is actually, like, pretty negligible compared to this new mechanism they've found.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The mechanism that we have now identified regulates body fat mass independently of leptin, and it is possible that leptin combined with activation of the internal body scales can become an effective treatment for obesity, said Professor Claes Ohlsson at Gothenburg University.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, they're saying to lose weight, we should just... sit down?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, they're saying to lose weight, we should just... sit down?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! Professor Claes Ohlsson says that when you sit down, your internal body scales give an extremely accurate measure. As a result, the body metabolizes excess fat and you lose weight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! Professor Claes Ohlsson says that when you sit down, your internal body scales give an extremely accurate measure. As a result, the body metabolizes excess fat and you lose weight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We believe that the internal body scales give an inaccurately low measure when you sit down. As a result you eat more and gain weight, says Ohlsson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] So, all those standing desks? Totally overrated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, all those standing desks? Totally overrated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he recommends reconsidering that standing desk and, uh, investing in a *really* comfortable chair.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he recommends reconsidering that standing desk and, uh, investing in a really comfortable chair.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Looks like you may want to take another look at investing in that standing desk after all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's, like, the best news I've heard all day. Time to kick back!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's, like, the best news I've heard all day. Time to kick back!
